instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message:
Hello guys,

I have no ppvcore signal on my 820-3209 board. I replaced U7400 and also Q7510, Q7520 and Q7550 but I had no luck. There is still no VCore signal (on L7510) and I can't figure out why.
I also replaced R7402 but still no luck (Pin1 of R7402 8.4V - Pin2 350mV).
When I plug the power cable in, I get a green light, orange light and also the fan spins.

I hope you can help me out!
Thanks a lot!!!

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Corrosion under PCH can cause this. CPUIMVP_VR_ON present at U7400?

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message:
Hello,

yes CPUIMVP_VR_ON is present. Whats the best thing I could do next?

Thank you!

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Question is how did this happen? Any history?

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Yes, the Macbook officially doesn't run of the battery and the user just worked with it by using the power cord. Then the fans started to get louder and louder and finally, after 15 minutes the screen went black and the problem I mentioned above occurred.

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Probably crap under SMC. Inspect board closer for corrosion.

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: I just took a closer look and there is absolutely no corrosion near the SMC. I am clueless...

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message:
Still I suspect the SMC. The fans running high indicated a sensor issue so could be SMC. Not running off battery is usually SMC. 
The no Vcore is because the CPU is not talking to U7400 to set the output voltage. There are 100 reasons for the CPU not to run of course. Is ALL_SYS_PWRGD present?

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message:
Hello,
yes I have 3.3V on ALL_SYS_PWRGD!
Do you thing replacing the SMC from a donor board would fix that issue?

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Cannot say anything for sure. No Vcore can have 100 different causes. I base my SMC diagnoses on the fact that it also did not work from battery. But it could easily be anything else.

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message:
Thanks for your help!
I will replace the SMC and keep you informed.

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message:
So, I now replaced the SMC and the board start working again, thanks a lot dukefawks.

The thing which is suspicious to me is that after I put the logicboard in my ultrasonic cleaner like every other board, I had no green light (no onewire) anymore. 
When I check the onewire circuit with U7000, I have these values:

- pin 19 & 20 (VCC) = present
- pin 3 (ACIN) = 4.4V
- pin 13 (CHGR_RST_L) = 0V
- pin 14 (CHGR_ACOK) = 0V

for testing purposes, I replaced U7000 but nothing changed.

Does someone have an idea what could be bad?

Thank you!

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Check your soldering. Use a good flux and touch each of your pins with the iron.

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: I checked it again, everything soldered fine - problem still there.

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message:
CHGR_RST_L is low so probably SMC_RESET is low too. Remove J5100 for a start, then check corrosion around U5010 and value of R5000.
Of course disconnect trackpad cable first to rule that out!

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message:
Hello,

yes SMC_RESET is low.

I now removed J5100 and replaced U6990 because I thought that this chip could be bad because I get only 1V on the boost pin. [B](nothing changed)[/B]
Why do I only get 1V boost with a new chip? Would it be possible that my replaced SMC went bad during the ultrasonic cleaning?

Then I replaced U5010 as well as R5000 and C6998. [B](nothing changed)[/B]

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Why did you  replace U6990? Was 3V42 not present?

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Yes 3V42 was [B]NOT[/B] present. SHDN and VIN of U6990 are present but I have no 3.42V on the output.

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Probably a short on the output then, resistance to GND on 3V42?

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Yes, I measure a short to GND too (on 3V42), but I can´t figure out where. Would it be possible that there is corrosion under my newly soldered SMC after ultrasonic cleaning?

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Inject voltage and see what heats up. Start low at 1V and monitor current.

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Thank you, I just prepared everything but I have to use a old pc power supply like Louis in one of his videos. The thing is, he uses LEDs as a load to get high amps but that doesn't work for me when I use the 3.3V rail. Do you have an idea what I could use as a load?

threads.title: 820-3209 no VCore
threads.message: Yes, buy a $40 PSU on Ebay that has everything you need.
